desc.size: Shrub or small tree, to 8 m tall, trunk diameter to 30 cm. Crown open, rounded.

part.partText: light brown to gray, tinged with red, thin, shallowly fissured, scaly.
stout, upright, brown to dark reddish purple, hairy.
dark reddish purple, 7 - 9 mm long, egg-shaped, flattened, long-pointed, shiny.

alternate, with 1 - 2.5 cm long leafstalks; bright green above, silvery or white-waxy and bluish green beneath, 5 - 12 cm long, 1.5 - 3.5 cm wide, lanceolate to narrowly elliptic, base rounded to tapering, tip pointed, margins irregularly wavy-toothed, thick, firm, sometimes rusty-hairy beneath.

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in hairy, cylindrical catkins; female catkins loosely flowered, greenish, smaller than Salix discolor (1.5 - 3 cm long), scales dark brown, ovary hairy; male catkins fuzzy, soft, white or silvery, smaller than S. discolor (2 - 4 cm long), stamens 2, scales dark brown, anthers yellow; insect- and wind-pollinated.
a capsule; in elongated clusters; light brown, smaller than Salix discolor (8 - 12 mm long), flask-shaped, finely hairy; seeds with long, white, silky hairs attached; dispersed by wind and water.

similarSpecies.comments: Salix x conifera is distinguished from most other willows in the Chicago Region by having leaf margins that are not distinctly toothed or down-curved (revolute). Salix bebbiana is similar but has gray-hairy leaves. Salix discolor, one of the parents of S. x conifera, has relatively larger catkins and fruit, with twigs and leaves that do not remain hairy into maturity. Its other parent, S. humilis, is a much smaller shrub with revolute (down-curved) leaf margins.

speciesPage.flowering: Early April to early May, before the leaves.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: In the Chicago Region, Salix x conifera is common in the marshy and swampy ground of shrub-dominated communities, bottomland woods, and moist prairies. Occurs along lakes, streams, roads, and railroads. May also be found in ditches, fens, bogs, and sandy areas.

notes.comments: Salix x conifera is a hybrid between S. discolor and S. humilis, two species common in the Chicago Region.

etymology.comments: Salix is the Latin word for willow. Conifera means “cone-bearing.”
